title: 104_hr3434
content:
The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" limits representation or advising of certain foreign entities. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" imposes restrictions on individuals who act as agents or attorneys for foreign governments or political parties within 10 years after their government service ends. Penalties are outlined in section 216 of Title 18, United States Code. Attorneys representing foreign entities in matters involving the United States may face penalties under section 216 of Title 18, United States Code. Attorneys representing foreign entities in the United States may be penalized under section 216 of Title 18, United States Code. The restrictions apply to the President and individuals subject to subsections (c), (d), or (e). Definitions include 'compensation' as any payment for services, 'government of a foreign country' as defined in the Foreign Agents Registration Act, and 'foreign political party' as defined in the same Act. The Agents Registration Act of 1938 defines 'United States' and 'State' and the amendment made by subsection (a) takes effect on January 1, 1997, with exceptions for certain individuals. SEC. 3. CROSS-OVER LOBBYING. The text discusses additional restrictions on former executive branch officers and employees, as well as former members of Congress and employees of the legislative branch, regarding lobbying activities within a year of leaving their positions. Former GS-15 employees of the legislative branch who lobby the executive branch within a year of leaving their position will be punished under section 216. SEC. 4. FELONS.

Former Members of Congress, former high-salary legislative employees, and certain executive branch employees convicted of a felony are prohibited from lobbying for compensation.

SEC. 5. EXEMPTION BASED ON REGISTRATION UNDER LOBBYING ACT.

Amendment to the Foreign Agents Registration Act exempts individuals engaged in lobbying activities who have registered.

SEC. 6. CIVIL PENALTIES. SEC. 6. CIVIL PENALTIES.

Amendment to the Foreign Agents Registration Act introduces civil penalties of up to $50,000 for each violation knowingly committed.
